Abi Tyas Tunggal

Apr 12

Seeking Alpha and Serious Wrinkles in Time and Space

In the professional investment business we are all agents, managing other peoples’ money. The prime directive, as Keynes knew so well, is first and last to keep your job. To do this, he explained that you must never, ever be wrong on your own. To prevent this calamity, professional investors pay ruthless attention to what other investors in general are doing. The great majority go with the flow, either completely or partially. This creates herding, or momentum, which drives prices far above or far below fair price. [source]

While thinking outside the box doesn’t guarantee impressive returns, it may be a prerequisite. The most important thing is to think differently and better. How can we encourage our members to think more? The Dish is our answer.

The other benefit of the Dish — it helps us think more too. That’s the most important thing, we’re managing people’s retirement after all.

And yes, we too pay ruthless attention to what other investors are doing. The difference is we look at more than just investment news. That’s why you’ll see more than news on the Dish.

As Charlie Munger says,

Well, the first rule is that you can’t really know anything if you just remember isolated facts and try and bang ’em back. If the facts don’t hang together on a latticework of theory, you don’t have them in a usable form.
You’ve got to have models in your head. [source]

We’re not about isolated facts, the most important thing to us is creating long term value for you — our customer. That’s why we’re not only focusing on technology and investment news.

The Dish is our place to share what we’ve been thinking about, and we hope that you will do the same.

Considering that, one thing I’ve been thinking about lately is just how long the average person’s investment in their Super is. Let’s say you start working at 16 and you retire at 65. That’s 49 years. A friend recently said, “there are serious wrinkles in time and space at these lengths of time”.

He’s right. In the past 50 years we’ve seen technology disrupt everything. It almost always results in a winner-take-all market. Look at Google vs. Yahoo or Facebook vs. Myspace. It sure seems to me the world’s most wonderful companies don’t leave much left over for second place.

No one at Spaceship will pretend to know what is coming, but that doesn’t stop us thinking about it. We will do everything in our power to not be part of,

today’s weak-kneed asset-management companies [ensuring] that their portfolios never deviate much from average results. That discourages clients from fleeing and enables firms to keep earning fat fees — maximizing their own returns while minimizing those of the clients. [source]

We Dare to Be Great.

This just in: you can’t take the same actions as everyone else and expect to outperform. [source]

Superannuation is challenging. We know it’s a tough job. We must act in what we consider to be the best interests of the beneficiary — our customers — trying to get superior returns and avoiding unacceptable losses.

We think the right approach is a both discipline and hard work.

We know it’s not easy. That’s why the Dish is key. You can let us know that what we are thinking about isn’t as important as we think it is. It’s your Superannuation, you should know who’s looking after it and you should know what they’re thinking.

Thanks to Hayden Bleasel, Jordan Hughes, and Anna Cheng.
